explanation:
int32: need the typedef/definition to confirm the parameter is a plain integer type (not a macro or type with side-effects) so that assignments to it would be actual parameter modifications.
exit: prototype/definition of exit is required to ensure it is a normal library function (no macro that could rewrite/modify the Status parameter in-place).
EXIT_SUCCESS, EXIT_FAILURE: definitions/macros are required to confirm they expand to constant integer expressions (not to code that could modify the parameter).
UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData: listed as a callee in the static graph — if OS_ApplicationExit calls this (or a macro expands to it) its implementation could contain statements that modify the parameter; its definition is needed to check for parameter modification.
UT_ExecuteBasicHandler: likewise a direct callee in the static graph; its implementation or macro wrapper could modify local parameters passed into OS_ApplicationExit via side effects or macro expansions.
UT_GetStubEntry, UT_SetHandlerFunction, UT_DefaultStubImpl, UtAssert_Abort: these are direct callees of the UT_* helpers above. Include their definitions because the helper functions may delegate work to them; any of them could contain code that (via macro expansion or indirect reference) modifies the Status parameter. Reviewing these ensures no hidden modification paths exist.
